location: Sebastopol Center for the Arts, 282 S High St, Sebastopol, CA 95472
description:
Out of Stock
      
    




Abstract Collage Minis - Create A Series

  
    
      
        
          $130.00
        
      
    
  

Sunday, February 8, 2026; 11 AM - 3 PMFee: $115 + $15 materials feeAge: 16+ Participants: min. 8In this new workshop, French-American collage artist Catherine Cruz will teach you how to create a dynamic series of abstract collages using elements such as color, line and shape.  You will work on four small wood panels to compose a cohesive series. Working on several panels at once offers several advantages, including greater creative momentum, the ability to build a strong thematic connection between pieces, and a way to maintain creative flow.  This technique allows for a deeper exploration of an idea or theme than is possible with a single piece. We will start with short composition exercises to discuss design principles and abstraction.  Then Catherine will demonstrate her method for mounting papers on the panels.  You will have ample time to select papers and create your designs. What you’ll learn from this workshop: Reliable method for layering collage papers, Creative ways to explore abstraction, Techniques for creating a cohesive series, Strategies for refining your compositionIMPORTANT: Instructions for where to purchase your materials and how to prepare them is provided in the attached PDF. We will take a short break for lunch between 12:30 and 1:00 pm so please bring your lunch and a beverage.   About the instructor: Catherine Cruz is a French-American artist whose work is informed by textures and patterns created by the passing of time and the effects of the natural elements on the built environment.  She holds a Bachelor of Science in interior design and she worked in the field of architectural design and green building certification for over 25 years.  She has taught collage and mixed media workshops in the Bay Area and in France since 2019, and this is her fifth year at the Sebastopol Center for the Arts.  Her studio is located in Sebastopol and she participates in Art Trails Open Studios.  You may contact Catherine at beyouartstudio@gmail.com.  Check out Catherine’s other classes here:  https://wwws.sebarts.org/visual-arts-classes.

title: Printing with Wayne! Panel Discussion — Sebastopol Center For the Arts, California
location: Sebastopol Center for the Arts, 282 S High St, Sebastopol, CA 95472
description:
Printing with Wayne! Panel Discussion

  
    
      
        
          $25.00
        
      
    
  

Sunday, February 8th, 2026; 1-3pm$25 (entry to exhibition included)* BRING YOUR RECEIPT CONFIRMATION FROM PHONE OR PRINTED *Join us for a moderated panel discussion with Emily York and Courtney Sennish, two Master Printers who worked extensively with Wayne Thiebaud at Crown Point Press.  Master Printers are the technical wizards that worked side by side with Thiebaud, allowing him to achieve his artistic vision in printed form.  Learn how Thiebaud approached printmaking and how he made changes and decisions along the way.  The panel is moderated by Alan Porter, Curator of the Unknown Thiebaud exhibition.Emily York is the senior master printer at Crown Point Press in San Francisco, where she has worked as a printer since 2004. In her 22 years with the press she has led and assisted nearly 50 etching projects with artists such as Wayne Thiebaud, Ed Ruscha, Robert Bechtle, Laura Owens, Julie Mehertu, Nathan Olivera and Hilary Pecis. Emily is the author of the Crown Point Press publication, Magical Secrets about Aquatint: Spit Bite, Sugar Lift & Other Etched Tones Step-by-Step. Emily is from St. Helena, California and earned her BFA from the University of California at Santa Cruz in 1999.Courtney Sennish is a master printer specializing in copper plate etching and photogravure. She earned her BFA in printmaking from the Rhode Island School of Design in 2013 after which she apprenticed under master printer Paul Taylor at Renaissance Press to focus on the photogravure process. After moving to the Bay Area she worked as a printer and plate maker for Mullowney Printing while she completed her MFA at California College of the Arts. For over nine years, Courtney worked as a printer for Crown Point Press, leading or assisting on all artist projects from 2015-2024. Since gaining the title of master printer, she has led Crown Point Press projects with artists including Ed Ruscha, John Chiara, Gay Outlaw, Odili Donald Odita, Patricia Treib, Alyson Shotz, Matt Mullican and Darren Almond. Courtney’s experience also includes freelance project management for various artists, leading print demonstrations and workshops, studying paper making at Awagami Factory and becoming an adjunct professor at California College of the Arts in print media.

title: ZEN & Heart Practices
location: Sebastopol Community Cultural Center – Annex, 425 Morris St, Sebastopol, CA, 95472
description:
The Occidental Laguna Sangha is a Zen Buddhist Sangha located in Sebastopol, California. Though our emphasis is primarily Zen we integrate mindfulness and other teachings from the Vipassana and Tibetan traditions into our practice. We believe that everything that comes our way is an opportunity for opening — our work in the world, our everyday tasks, our relationships — everything is an opportunity to practice the Bodhisattva ideals of mindfulness, compassion, generosity and kindness. 
We meet every Sunday at the Youth Annex, Sebastopol Cultural Center from 9-10:30. By Donation ($15 suggested). The Guiding Teacher is Bruce Fortin with 50 years of meditation experience. 
Our name incorporates “Occidental,” as this is the town where we first started meeting together. The word also carries the meaning “Western,” where the Buddha Dharma is now being established. “Laguna” is where we currently meet and meditate together, right next to the beautiful Laguna de Santa Rosa in Sebastopol California. 
The Sangha is respectful of all the teachings and schools of Buddhism and includes practitioners of all levels, from complete beginners to the very experienced. All are welcome to practice with us. 
The guiding teacher for the Sangha is Bruce Fortin. He was ordained a Soto Zen Priest in the lineage of Suzuki Roshi in 1976 and has received Dharma Transmission to teach in that lineage. He has also studied with a number of other teachers in the Tibetan and Vipassana traditions and his teachings reflect their influence.

title: Qigong for Health & Longevity
location: Sebastopol Community Cultural Center – Main Hall, 390 Morris St, Sebastopol, CA, 95472, United States
description:
Qigong is one of the longevity practices of Traditional Chinese Medicine. This class is taught by advanced qigong teacher, Shifu Michael, he teaches qigong following the seasonal influences of the year. Classes include warm-ups, purging, gathering and tonifying the organ/meridians of the body, and quiet sitting meditation. Most health conditions including aging are benefited by regular qigong practice. Open to all, beginners to advanced! 
Michael’s qigong class includes individual exercises, circle walking, and a new Qigong Taichi form called Taichi 18. 
Mondays, Wednesdays, & Fridays
10:30 AM – 11:30 AM
$10 drop-in fee 
About the Instructor
Michael Rinaldini, Qigong Teacher and Daoist priest. He is the director of Qigong & Daoist Training Center, Sebastopol. He has been teaching qigong for nearly 30 years, both locally and nationally. His teachings emphasize the healing of the whole person, regardless of the health condition of the student. 
Questions? Contact the instructor at lichangdao@gmail.com or visit his website at qigongdragon.com

title: Dog Training
location: Sebastopol Community Cultural Center – Main Hall, 390 Morris St, Sebastopol, CA, 95472, United States
description:
Mondays
6:30pm-7:30pm
Main Hall
Drop-In Registration HERE
This course is designed to meet your young pup’s social, physical, and mental needs, helping them reach their full potential as a balanced dog. 
Class Requirements: 

Proof of vaccinations: Puppies should have received at least 2 rounds of vaccines and must have been in your home for at least 2 weeks.
Please refrain from feeding your pup a full breakfast before class to increase their motivation for food-based rewards.
Bring your pup’s breakfast, favorite high-value treats (cut into small pieces), a treat pouch or snack storage pockets, a safe and interactive toy, a towel or yoga mat or raised bed for your pup to rest on, a 6-foot leash with a secure snap or clip, a flat collar with identification tags, and any other collar that is safely fitted and removable for playtime.
For safety reasons, please avoid bringing items such as costumes, bandanas, hair bows, or ribbons that could pose a choking hazard to other puppies during playtime.
Additionally, please ensure your pup can move freely in any equipment and refrain from using front-clip no-pull harnesses.

Class Questions? Contact Judah Johnson at Sonomacountycosmiccanine@gmail.com or call (415) 410-8757
Registration Questions? Contact sccc@seb.org or call (707) 823-1511

title: Danceypants
location: Sebastopol Community Cultural Center – Annex, 425 Morris St, Sebastopol, CA, 95472
description:
Remember how when you were younger (or like, a month ago maybe?) and you found yourself in your bathroom with a hairbrush pretending you were in a music video? 
That’s the idea behind this class. 
We have fun, we warm up, we learn a routine altogether, and in creating a non-judgmental environment we allow our inner performer to take the (metaphorical) stage. 
All shapes and sizes welcome! You absolutely do not have to look a certain way to show up to this class. Get your Danceypants on, and learn new and retro moves to 80s, 90s, and 00s pop, hip hop, world music & more. 
Wear comfy things you can move in (workout gear / clean sneakers / no jeans!) and bring a hair tie / water. 
$15 w/online registration, $20 drop-in   |   18+   |   BEGINNERS WELCOME

title: Poetic Medicine: 02/10/26 — Sebastopol Center For the Arts, California
location: Sebastopol Center for the Arts, 282 S High St, Sebastopol, CA 95472
description:
Out of Stock
      
    




Poetic Medicine: 02/10-02/24 2026

  
    
      
        
          $40.00
        
      
    
  

Tuesday, February 10, 17, 24, 2026; 4:00 – 5:30pm$40 for 3 sessionsMax 18 Attendees, Pre-registration required(We are unable to offer refunds or transfers for this class. If you cannot attend, please consider it a donation. Thank you!)The practice of “poem making” offers a means to express the metaphors and meaning of the joys and suffering we experience in ourselves and bear witness to in others. Poetry can be a salve for the heart and soul. It is a way of speaking what is true in our hearts and is often difficult to access without a creative spark. You do not have to be a "poet" or even a "writer" to allow words and feelings to pour through your pen.Redwing Keyssar has been leading "poetic medicine" sessions through her work in Palliative Care at UCSF for the past 5 years. Her work has created an international community of people who, by listening to and writing poetry together, have healed wounds of grief and loss, helped "wounded healers," and provided resiliency to move forward on our life paths.Writing poetry in community is a bit like attending a meditation retreat. The instruction for most beginners when learning to meditate is to simply bring oneself back to the breath, each time the mind wanders. In poem-making, the instruction is to bring oneself back to the heart and along with a deep breath, see if one can open a little bit wider. When we witness each other in this process, in a circle of open-heartedness, something magical happens!This is an IN-PERSON gathering to establish a strong and safe creative community. We are all poets!About the Instructor: Judith Redwing Keyssar, RN has traversed an amazing 35+ year journey in the healing arts/healthcare. Redwing is an educator, end-of-life doula, author, poet, song-writer, ceremonialist, national presenter and frequent contributor to public issues about Palliative and End of Life Care. Redwing is currently the Director of Education at the MERI Center for Education in Palliative Care at UCSF/Mt. Zion. Her professional career includes being the Clinical Director at Zen Hospice Project and the Director of Palliative Care and Nursing at Jewish Family and Children’s Services from 2004-2018. She is a founder and adjunct faculty member of the California State University Shiley/Haynes Institute of Palliative Care, and has taught courses at OLLI at Sonoma State. Redwing is the author of an award-winning book, “Last Acts of Kindness; Lessons for the Living from the Bedsides of the Dying” and is the recipient of numerous awards in the field of Palliative Care. After studying with John Fox at the Institute for Poetic Medicine, her passion for using poetry as a healing modality has led to the development of a successful international program in Poetic Medicine, through her work at the UCSF MERI Center. Learn more about her here: https://redwingkeyssar.com/

description:

Poetic Medicine: 02/10-02/24 2026

Tuesday, February 10, 17, 24, 2026; 4:00 – 5:30pm$40 for 3 sessionsMax 18 Attendees, Pre-registration required(We are unable to offer refunds or transfers for this class. If you cannot attend, please consider it a donation. Thank you!)The practice of “poem making” offers a means to express the metaphors and meaning of the joys and suffering we experience in ourselves and bear witness to in others. Poetry can be a salve for the heart and soul. It is a way of speaking what is true in our hearts and is often difficult to access without a creative spark. You do not have to be a "poet" or even a "writer" to allow words and feelings to pour through your pen.Redwing Keyssar has been leading "poetic medicine" sessions through her work in Palliative Care at UCSF for the past 5 years. Her work has created an international community of people who, by listening to and writing poetry together, have healed wounds of grief and loss, helped "wounded healers," and provided resiliency to move forward on our life paths.Writing poetry in community is a bit like attending a meditation retreat. The instruction for most beginners when learning to meditate is to simply bring oneself back to the breath, each time the mind wanders. In poem-making, the instruction is to bring oneself back to the heart and along with a deep breath, see if one can open a little bit wider. When we witness each other in this process, in a circle of open-heartedness, something magical happens!This is an IN-PERSON gathering to establish a strong and safe creative community. We are all poets!About the Instructor: Judith Redwing Keyssar, RN has traversed an amazing 35+ year journey in the healing arts/healthcare. Redwing is an educator, end-of-life doula, author, poet, song-writer, ceremonialist, national presenter and frequent contributor to public issues about Palliative and End of Life Care. Redwing is currently the Director of Education at the MERI Center for Education in Palliative Care at UCSF/Mt. Zion. Her professional career includes being the Clinical Director at Zen Hospice Project and the Director of Palliative Care and Nursing at Jewish Family and Children’s Services from 2004-2018. She is a founder and adjunct faculty member of the California State University Shiley/Haynes Institute of Palliative Care, and has taught courses at OLLI at Sonoma State. Redwing is the author of an award-winning book, “Last Acts of Kindness; Lessons for the Living from the Bedsides of the Dying” and is the recipient of numerous awards in the field of Palliative Care. After studying with John Fox at the Institute for Poetic Medicine, her passion for using poetry as a healing modality has led to the development of a successful international program in Poetic Medicine, through her work at the UCSF MERI Center. Learn more about her here: https://redwingkeyssar.com/

description:
A morning Danceypants class!!
Remember how when you were younger (or like, a month ago maybe?) and you found yourself in your bathroom with a hairbrush pretending you were in a music video? 
That’s the idea behind this class. 
We have fun, we warm up, we learn a routine altogether, and in creating a non-judgmental environment we allow our inner performer to take the (metaphorical) stage.

title: Qigong for Health & Longevity
location: Sebastopol Community Cultural Center – Main Hall, 390 Morris St, Sebastopol, CA, 95472, United States
description:
Qigong is one of the longevity practices of Traditional Chinese Medicine. This class is taught by advanced qigong teacher, Shifu Michael, he teaches qigong following the seasonal influences of the year. Classes include warm-ups, purging, gathering and tonifying the organ/meridians of the body, and quiet sitting meditation. Most health conditions including aging are benefited by regular qigong practice. Open to all, beginners to advanced! 
Michael’s qigong class includes individual exercises, circle walking, and a new Qigong Taichi form called Taichi 18. 
Mondays, Wednesdays, & Fridays
10:30 AM – 11:30 AM
$10 drop-in fee 
About the Instructor
Michael Rinaldini, Qigong Teacher and Daoist priest. He is the director of Qigong & Daoist Training Center, Sebastopol. He has been teaching qigong for nearly 30 years, both locally and nationally. His teachings emphasize the healing of the whole person, regardless of the health condition of the student. 
Questions? Contact the instructor at lichangdao@gmail.com or visit his website at qigongdragon.com

title: Dog Training
location: Sebastopol Community Cultural Center – Main Hall, 390 Morris St, Sebastopol, CA, 95472, United States
description:
Wednesdays
6:30pm-7:30pm
Main Hall
Drop-In Registration HERE
This course is designed to meet your young pup’s social, physical, and mental needs, helping them reach their full potential as a balanced dog. 
Class Requirements: 

Proof of vaccinations: Puppies should have received at least 2 rounds of vaccines and must have been in your home for at least 2 weeks.
Please refrain from feeding your pup a full breakfast before class to increase their motivation for food-based rewards.
Bring your pup’s breakfast, favorite high-value treats (cut into small pieces), a treat pouch or snack storage pockets, a safe and interactive toy, a towel or yoga mat or raised bed for your pup to rest on, a 6-foot leash with a secure snap or clip, a flat collar with identification tags, and any other collar that is safely fitted and removable for playtime.
For safety reasons, please avoid bringing items such as costumes, bandanas, hair bows, or ribbons that could pose a choking hazard to other puppies during playtime.
Additionally, please ensure your pup can move freely in any equipment and refrain from using front-clip no-pull harnesses.

Class Questions? Contact Judah Johnson at Sonomacountycosmiccanine@gmail.com
Registration Questions? Contact sccc@seb.org or call (707) 823-1511

title: Divine Voice
location: Sebastopol Community Cultural Center – Annex, 425 Morris St, Sebastopol, CA, 95472
description:
Divine Voice
with Kiranjot Kaur of Copper Wimmin
Indian Classical Note Singing as a Meditation
on Sound and Presence
Wednesday at 7:30 – 9 pm (time may run over by 15 min)
I believe that EVERYONE can sing and that we are each designed as divine instruments! 
In the tradition of Indian Classical music we surrender to the practice, to music herself. It is a practice
of letting go of who we think we are and any limitations we believe we have. 
It is an exercise of becoming present and allowing music to move through like breath through a
beautiful flute. We can gently allow each note to brush the strings of our hearts instrument and
become the voice of our soul. 
This vocal practice works on breath support, intonation, vocal range, dexterity and tone, note
recognition, projection and presence. 
This class is open to ALL no experience needed! We spend the first 45 minutes in a blissful call and
response note singing practice and end with chanting and or a composition in a particular Raag (set of
notes). 
My teacher, Dr.Ustad Narinder Singh Sandhu, taught me that: 
“You do not need to know anything about music to sing.
You do not need to have a beautiful voice or talent to sing.
The only thing that you need is love.” 
Kiranjot Kaur is a vocalist, founding member of Copper Wimmin, Kundalini Yoga teacher, and Indian classical music instructor, with a deep devotion to the Divine Mother and A Course in Miracles. Copper Wimmin gained recognition through appearances on Democracy Now and the Showtime series The L Word, where their song “Bleeding Rivers” was featured. 
In 2006, Kiranjot refocused her career toward Indian classical music, dedicating five years to living and studying under the tutelage of her beloved teacher, Dr. Ustad Narindar Singh, in Amritsar, India. Shifting away from traditional performances where the audience is separate from the performer, Kiranjot now merges her early experiences of communal singing with Sweet Honey in the Rock and Bobby McFerrin, alongside her deep love for Indian music and Kirtan traditions. 
In 2014, Kiranjot was introduced to A Course in Miracles, and has since steadily integrated its daily lessons into her life. She now offers a unique blend of Indian classical notes and A Course in Miracles songs, sung in the Kirtan style of call and response. Kiranjot invites everyone to experience the transformative healing power of their own voice in the practice of singing together as ONE. 
From her journeys through India to Chile and back, Kiranjot has discovered her greatest joy is inspiring everyone regardless of their singing experience, to use their voices as a method for quieting the mind, surrendering to presence, and revolutionary self-love. 
For more information please email: kiranjot@mantramamas.org 
First class: by donation
Drop in class: $25 
5 class stamp card: $100 (must be used within 8 weeks)
Class pass card available in person at first class or online HERE

Paint Your Pet in Watercolor: SebArts & Humane Society of Sonoma County — Sebastopol Center For the Arts, California
location: Sebastopol Center for the Arts, 282 S High St, Sebastopol, CA 95472
description:
Out of Stock
      
    




Paint Your Pet in Watercolor: SebArts & Humane Society of SoCo

  
    
      
        
          $95.00
        
      
    
  

Saturday, February 21, 2026; 1:00 – 4:00pm$80.00 + $15 Materials FeeJoin us for a collaborative community event, a joyful, inclusive art experience celebrating the bond between people and animals while supporting local art education and animal welfare. We invite participants to create a portrait of their beloved pet, under the guidance of an experienced Teaching Artist, with proceeds shared between SebArts and the Humane Society of Sonoma County. The event will blend creativity and compassion - core values shared by both organizations. Paint Your Pet is a 3 hour guided painting workshop where participants bring a photo of their pet (or choose from adoptable pets featured by the Humane Society) and learn to create a custom portrait using watercolor paint. Celebrate the human animal bond through art and creative expression while raising funds to support SebArts art programs and the Humane Society of Sonoma County’s animal care and adoption services.About the Instructor: Hannah Day received her BA in Visual Arts with an emphasis on drawing and printmaking from University of San Diego, then attended University of Hawaii at Manoa to receive her MFA in printmaking. Hannah’s etchings have been internationally shown and collected, but her personal practice also includes paper cutting, graphite, watercolor, mixed media, and murals. She have taught all ages and many formats (kids, teens, adults, college, private lessons, camps, etc) and many mediums. These days Hannah has been teaching primarily paper cutting but also enjoys teaching drawing, painting and printmaking.

ReVision: Writers ReGroup — Sebastopol Center For the Arts, California
location: Sebastopol Center for the Arts, 282 S High St, Sebastopol, CA 95472
description:
ReVision: Writers ReGroup 2/22/26

  
    
      
        
          $35.00
        
      
    
  

Sunday, February 22, 2026; 1pm-3:30pm$35 Write your way into a productive and rewarding relationship with revision!Session Focus: Whole-body Characters We’ll explore ways to create vivid people on the page and strengthen other elements through character, including point of view, sense of place, and emotional resonance.Revision is to a first draft what marriage is to falling head-over heels. It is to free write what deep friendship is to casual meeting. Revision takes time, skill, caring, and fortitude. It asks that we be generous and also draw boundaries. It presents us with choices that challenge what we believe to be true about others and ourselves. Revision is not for the faint of heart, but for writers committed to their relationship with creative expression through all the rough patches. Revision allows writers to investigate their heart work and intentions and stay true.I’ll share a process that I call “Master Craft Juggling,” which incorporates my Nine Ways to Mastery approach for writing fiction, memoir, and nonfiction. The session includes a craft presentation, group discussion, and writing time.You will:• Gain perspectives and techniques for masterful revision• Build community with writers who may become trusted readers for your projects• Improve your writing and writing practice through revision• Move your projects toward publicationPlease bring your:• Open mind• Fiction or nonfiction free write, early draft, or manuscript in progress• Tools and materials for writing during the session• Writing and revision challenges to discuss, particularly as relate to the session focusThe workshop will be offered periodically with a particular focus each time. Check the schedule, and sign up when you’re ready to revise.About the Instructor: Christine Walker is a visual artist, author, and strategic visioning consultant. Her published books include the novel “Tap Dancing at the Bluebird,” the memoir “A Painter’s Garden: Cultivating the Creative Life,” the children’s book and songs “Wooleycat’s Musical Theater,” and books on writing craft — “A Writer’s Resolution: A Guided Journal for Realizing a Rewarding Writing Practice” and, for publication in 2027, “Our Writing Minds in Play: The Nine Ways Guide to Masterful Fiction & Memoir.” Her paintings are exhibited in galleries and corporate and private collections. She holds an MFA in Writing and Literature in Fiction from Bennington College and an MA in Creative Arts Interdisciplinary from San Francisco State University. The Bennington program promised: “Read one hundred books. Write one.” This motto inspired her to design teaching frameworks and courses—Master Craft Juggling, Nine Ways to Mastery, Read to Write Books—to help writers elevate their writing practice and readers to engage more deeply in enjoying and discussing books. Throughout her multi-faceted creative career, she’s found that resilience is key to a rewarding career in the arts. She brings that resilience to teaching revision as a writing skill, as well as a practice. 
































        
          
            
              Add to cart

Fridays, February 27 - Apr 3, 2026 (6 sessions)5pm - 7:30pm$205 + $45 clay feeMaximum 10 studentsThere will be an initial demo on throwing and trimming, and you will also receive one-on-one guidance.The class will end with learning to attach a handle to a cup and glazing the cup with your chosen colors.The instructor will clear glaze your pieces once they have been bisqued at the studio.Come prepared to get messy and have fun!About the Instructor: James Thomson has been a ceramics studio facilitator with Sebastopol Center of the Arts for over 5 years. Collage Your Story with Catherine Cruz — Sebastopol Center For the Arts, California
location: Sebastopol Center for the Arts, 282 S High St, Sebastopol, CA 95472
description:
Collage Your Story with Catherine Cruz: Mar 1, 2026

  
    
      
        
          $130.00
        
      
    
  

Sunday, March 1, 2026; 11:00am - 3:00pmFee: $115 + $15 materials feeAges 16 and up; Located in Dining Room at SebArtsJoin French-American collage artist Catherine Cruz for a special, personalized workshop designed just for you! The word collage comes from the French verb coller, meaning "to glue," and is all about merging various materials to tell a visual story. Much like our lives, which are shaped by countless moments and experiences, collage pieces bring together fragments that reveal hidden connections and untold narratives. In this class, you’ll reflect on what matters most to you and how that can be expressed through art. Catherine will help you release the need for perfection and trust your creative instincts. By the end of the workshop, you’ll not only have a finished artwork but also a deeper connection to your creative potential and a renewed love for the art of collage.What you’ll learn: Creative ways to incorporate your personal story in your art, Methods for sourcing interesting collage papers, Techniques for crafting textured, multi-layered collages, Strategies for refining your compositionYou are highly encouraged to bring your own papers to personalize your artwork like ephemera that represents your life, copies of photos, old letters, books, papers from memorable experiences or travels, or documents that hold meaning. If you’re not comfortable using these documents, you should make color copies of them. For this process, it is also best to make laser copies of your photographs.Supplies provided by instructor: some collage papers, acrylic medium, brushesCLICK HERE TO READ DOCUMENT PRIOR TO PURCHASING CLASSAbout the instructor: Catherine Cruz is a French-American artist whose work is informed by the textures and patterns created by the passing of time and the effects of the natural elements on the built environment. She has taught collage and mixed media in the Bay Area and France since 2019. Her background is in interior design and green building certification. She works from her home studio in Sebastopol, CA, and participates in Art Trails Open Studios. You may contact Catherine at beyouartstudio@gmail.com.

title: Collage Your Story with Catherine Cruz — Sebastopol Center For the Arts, California
description:
Collage Your Story with Catherine Cruz: Mar 1, 2026

  
    
      
        
          $130.00
        
      
    
  

Sunday, March 1, 2026; 11:00am - 3:00pmFee: $115 + $15 materials feeAges 16 and up; Located in Dining Room at SebArtsJoin French-American collage artist Catherine Cruz for a special, personalized workshop designed just for you! The word collage comes from the French verb coller, meaning "to glue," and is all about merging various materials to tell a visual story. Much like our lives, which are shaped by countless moments and experiences, collage pieces bring together fragments that reveal hidden connections and untold narratives. In this class, you’ll reflect on what matters most to you and how that can be expressed through art. Catherine will help you release the need for perfection and trust your creative instincts. By the end of the workshop, you’ll not only have a finished artwork but also a deeper connection to your creative potential and a renewed love for the art of collage.What you’ll learn: Creative ways to incorporate your personal story in your art, Methods for sourcing interesting collage papers, Techniques for crafting textured, multi-layered collages, Strategies for refining your compositionYou are highly encouraged to bring your own papers to personalize your artwork like ephemera that represents your life, copies of photos, old letters, books, papers from memorable experiences or travels, or documents that hold meaning. If you’re not comfortable using these documents, you should make color copies of them. For this process, it is also best to make laser copies of your photographs.Supplies provided by instructor: some collage papers, acrylic medium, brushesCLICK HERE TO READ DOCUMENT PRIOR TO PURCHASING CLASSAbout the instructor: Catherine Cruz is a French-American artist whose work is informed by the textures and patterns created by the passing of time and the effects of the natural elements on the built environment. She has taught collage and mixed media in the Bay Area and France since 2019. Her background is in interior design and green building certification. She works from her home studio in Sebastopol, CA, and participates in Art Trails Open Studios. You may contact Catherine at beyouartstudio@gmail.com.

Intro to Observational Drawing — Sebastopol Center For the Arts, California
location: Sebastopol Center for the Arts, 282 S High St, Sebastopol, CA 95472
description:
Out of Stock
      
    




Intro to Observational Drawing

  
    
      
        
          $65.00
        
      
    
  

Wednesday, March 4, 2026; 6-9PM$55 + $10 Materials FeeAges 16+In this one day introductory workshop, participants will get a peek into the process of building one’s drawing abilities through developing close observational skills and learning fundamental drawing techniques. If you find this intro helpful and want to keep exploring, you can sign up for the 3 week class one month later.This course is for anyone who wants to practice and advance their drawing skills - beginners, those who haven’t practiced in years, or any artists who just want to learn more and practice with consistent feedback and guidance. Learning to draw is truly learning to see - a skill that anyone can be taught, practice, and hone. Through demonstration, practice, and reflective discussion, this class will explore the foundations of classical drawing techniques in a low pressure environment. Observational drawing gives all artists a foundation of practical knowledge and skills that infinitely expands the possibilities of what one can create. If your ideas feel limited by your drawing skills, if you feel frustrated or stuck in your painting practice, or if you simply want to start drawing and are looking for a way to begin, this is the class for you. About the Instructor: Hannah Day received her BA in Visual Arts with an emphasis on drawing and printmaking from University of San Diego, then attended University of Hawaii at Manoa to receive her MFA in printmaking. Hannah’s etchings have been internationally shown and collected, but her personal practice also includes paper cutting, graphite, watercolor, mixed media, and murals. She have taught all ages and many formats (kids, teens, adults, college, private lessons, camps, etc) and many mediums. These days Hannah has been teaching primarily paper cutting but also enjoys teaching drawing, painting and printmaking.

title: Poetic Medicine: 03/10/26 — Sebastopol Center For the Arts, California
location: Sebastopol Center for the Arts, 282 S High St, Sebastopol, CA 95472
description:
Poetic Medicine: 03/10/26

  
    
      
        
          $15.00
        
      
    
  

Tuesday, March 10, 2026; 4:00 – 5:30pm$15.00Max 18 Attendees, Pre-registration required(We are unable to offer refunds or transfers for this class. If you cannot attend, please consider it a donation. Thank you!)The practice of “poem making” offers a means to express the metaphors and meaning of the joys and suffering we experience in ourselves and bear witness to in others. Poetry can be a salve for the heart and soul. It is a way of speaking what is true in our hearts and is often difficult to access without a creative spark. You do not have to be a "poet" or even a "writer" to allow words and feelings to pour through your pen.Redwing Keyssar has been leading "poetic medicine" sessions through her work in Palliative Care at UCSF for the past 5 years. Her work has created an international community of people who, by listening to and writing poetry together, have healed wounds of grief and loss, helped "wounded healers," and provided resiliency to move forward on our life paths.Writing poetry in community is a bit like attending a meditation retreat. The instruction for most beginners when learning to meditate is to simply bring oneself back to the breath, each time the mind wanders. In poem-making, the instruction is to bring oneself back to the heart and along with a deep breath, see if one can open a little bit wider. When we witness each other in this process, in a circle of open-heartedness, something magical happens!This is an IN-PERSON gathering to establish a strong and safe creative community. We are all poets!About the Instructor: Judith Redwing Keyssar, RN has traversed an amazing 35+ year journey in the healing arts/healthcare. Redwing is an educator, end-of-life doula, author, poet, song-writer, ceremonialist, national presenter and frequent contributor to public issues about Palliative and End of Life Care. Redwing is currently the Director of Education at the MERI Center for Education in Palliative Care at UCSF/Mt. Zion. Her professional career includes being the Clinical Director at Zen Hospice Project and the Director of Palliative Care and Nursing at Jewish Family and Children’s Services from 2004-2018. She is a founder and adjunct faculty member of the California State University Shiley/Haynes Institute of Palliative Care, and has taught courses at OLLI at Sonoma State. Redwing is the author of an award-winning book, “Last Acts of Kindness; Lessons for the Living from the Bedsides of the Dying” and is the recipient of numerous awards in the field of Palliative Care. After studying with John Fox at the Institute for Poetic Medicine, her passion for using poetry as a healing modality has led to the development of a successful international program in Poetic Medicine, through her work at the UCSF MERI Center. Learn more about her here: https://redwingkeyssar.com/

title: Clay Exploration Evenings: Lvl 2 — Sebastopol Center For the Arts, California
location: Sebastopol Center for the Arts, 282 S High St, Sebastopol, CA 95472
description:
Clay Exploration Evenings: Lvl 2, 3/12

  
    
      
        
          $255.00
        
      
    
  

Thursdays, March 12 - April 16, 2026 (6 sessions) 6 - 8:30pm$210 + $45 clay fee (pre-registration required)This course is designed for students wishing to explore hand-building techniques at an intermediate to advanced level and delve deeper into refining their clay skills. Each session will start with a demonstration of a specific technique related to functional and/or decorative pottery. Participants are invited to explore new ideas and to try pieces that might be of a more challenging nature. Some of what we can explore are freeform coil pots, soft slab work, hard slab technique, a variety of sculptural techniques and a sampling of the many stamping, carving and textural surface treatments on clay. We will investigate ways to use slips and glaze that will add color to the forms we create.About the Instructor: Michael Citrino has had a love affair with clay for over 50 years. After his college experience at California College of Arts and Crafts with Viola Frey and further work at Humboldt State University with Lew Merrick, he ran a stained glass business for 18 years. Michael and his wife left for Turkey in 1991 to teach in International Schools. For 26 years he taught K-12 art, including Ceramics, Drawing, Photography, Design and Sculpture at schools in six different countries. He started clay programs for High School and Middle School students at three of those schools. At four of these schools he offered after school and weekend ceramics sessions for teachers and parents. Michael’s work ranges from the traditional to the experimental and a wide swath in between. His approach to teaching is to help students explore the playful nature of the clay room and nurture a love for the possibilities that medium presents.

description:
Floor Loom Weaving: Exploring Lace Weave

  
    
      
        
          $325.00
        
      
    
  

Thursdays, March 19 - May 7, 2026; 9:30am - 12:30pm$325An 8 session class for new or experienced weavers. New students will go through the complete process of setting up a loom and weave a simple scarf or table linens using a pickup lace technique. Spring Bloom Watercolors — Sebastopol Center For the Arts, California
location: Sebastopol Center for the Arts, 282 S High St, Sebastopol, CA 95472
description:
Spring Bloom Watercolors

  
    
      
        
          $170.00
        
      
    
  

Saturday, March 21, 2026 10AM - 4PMCost: $130 + $40 materials feeCelebrate the full arrival of spring with a day of watercolor painting inspired by Sonoma County’s vibrant blooms—fresh cut California poppy, lupin, wild iris, wild roses, lilac, magnolia, daffodils, tulips, dwarf iris (Iris reticulata), crocus, grape hyacinth, and cherry, peach, and apple blossoms.Focus on building strong compositions using color, texture, light, and form, developed through wet washes, controlled washes, and textural techniques. Guided discussions explore the essential elements of visual art to help you create expressive, individual work.All materials provided, Space limited to 10 studentsDiscussion break 12:30pm. Please bring a brown bag lunchAbout the Instructor: Lynn Zachreson studied art at the University of Minnesota and San Jose State University—Painting, Printmaking: BA Fine Art. She has experience teaching all ages: Watercolor painting skills, 30+ years, Watercolor figure painting 20+ years, and Fine Art Basics with Mixed Media 20+ years. Lynn enjoys spending her time painting, teaching, long distance hiking, and gardening. View Lynn’s art here: https://lynnzachresonart.com/
